elements.content: Two series of lanthanide metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) formulated as {Ln2(TBrTA)3­(H2O)8­·2H2O} n [Ln = La (1), Ce (2), Pr (3), Nd (4), Sm (5), Eu (6), Gd (7), Tb (8), Dy (9)] series 1, {[Ln3(TBrTA)6]­[Ln­(H2O)8]­·6H2O} n [Ln = Ho (10), Er (11), Tm (12), Yb (13), Lu (14)] series 2, respectively, were synthesized via slow evaporation with tetrabromoterephthalic acid (H2TBrTA) and structurally characterized by X-ray crystallography, infrared spectroscopy, and thermal analysis. Lanthanide contraction effects result in a change in the structure from a two-dimensional (2D) MOF with sql topology for La–Dy (series 1) to a three-dimensional (3D) MOF with pcu network topology for Ho–Lu (series 2). Supramolecular interactions also evolve from Br···Br, Br···O, π–π, and hydrogen bonding interactions in series 1 to Br···Br and hydrogen bonding interactions in series 2. The nature of Br···Br interactions transition from a combination of type I, type II, and quasi-type I/type II in series 1 to only type II in series 2. Furthermore, as the size of the Ln­(III) ion decreases, the strength of the type II Br···Br interactions increases. The anionic frameworks in series 2 are charge balanced by [Ln­(H2O)8]3+ cations in the pores that are encapsulated by an unprecedented three-dimensional (3D) “Star of David” dodecamer water cluster. Photophysical studies demonstrate that TBrTA is an efficient sensitizer of Eu3+(5D0) and Tb3+(5D4) luminescence as excitation into ligand bands leads to bright red and green emission, respectively, the spectral profiles of which display only metal centered emission bands. Emission from compound 6 is significantly quenched in the presence of Fe3+ (87%) and Cu2+ (75%) ions mainly due to competitive absorption of excitation energy, which leads to an inner-filter effect. In addition, the emission of 6 is more than 85% quenched by nitroaromatic compounds (NACs) such as 4-nitrophenol, dinitrophenol, and trinitrophenol (picric acid) with competitive absorption, photoinduced electron transfer, and electrostatic processes the main mechanisms of quenching. This study is the first to show that X···X interactions in extended structures such as MOFs can be tuned with the lanthanide contraction and also reveals that Ln-TBrTA MOFs can be used as bifunctional sensors for the detection of Fe3+ and Cu2+ as well as explosive nitroaromatics.

elements.content: Two series of Ln-TBrTA metal−organic frameworks featuring halogen···halogen interactions which evolve across the lanthanide series also act as bifunctional sensors for transition metal ions and nitroaromatic explosives.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are extended two- and three-dimensional (2D and 3D) coordination networks consisting of metal ions or metal ion clusters bridged by polytopic organic ligands into well-defined, frame-like topologies. They have attracted considerable attention in recent times due to their fascinating topologies, inherent tunability, porosity and large internal surface areas leading to materials with potential applications in gas storage and separation, drug delivery, heterogeneous catalysis, chemical sensing, and magnetism. On the basis of the nature of metal ions and their coordination chemistry with various organic functionalities, the diversity of MOFs in terms of their structures and chemical properties is almost limitless.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are extended two- and three-dimensional (2D and 3D) coordination networks consisting of metal ions or metal ion clusters bridged by polytopic organic ligands into well-defined, frame-like topologies. They have attracted considerable attention in recent times due to their fascinating topologies, inherent tunability, porosity and large internal surface areas leading to materials with potential applications in gas storage and separation, drug delivery, heterogeneous catalysis, chemical sensing, and magnetism. On the basis of the nature of metal ions and their coordination chemistry with various organic functionalities, the diversity of MOFs in terms of their structures and chemical properties is almost limitless.

elements.content: Crystal engineering strategies, whereby intermolecular forces between molecular building blocks are manipulated to affect crystal packing, have evolved as a major approach in the design and synthesis of MOFs. Metal coordination and hydrogen bonds are the driving force of this effort, but other interactions such as π-interactions and halogen bonding have also been explored. Historically, most of the work on halogen bonding has been focused on organic compounds, yet in the past decade there has been a surge in the number of papers on halogen interactions in metal containing systems.
elements.clean_text: Crystal engineering strategies, whereby intermolecular forces between molecular building blocks are manipulated to affect crystal packing, have evolved as a major approach in the design and synthesis of MOFs. Metal coordination and hydrogen bonds are the driving force of this effort, but other interactions such as π-interactions and halogen bonding have also been explored. Historically, most of the work on halogen bonding has been focused on organic compounds, yet in the past decade there has been a surge in the number of papers on halogen interactions in metal containing systems.

elements.content: Halogen bonding interactions are due to a net attractive interaction between a region of depleted electron density, called a σ-hole, of an anisotropically polarized halogen atom (X) and an electron rich (or nucleophilic) region on another atom. In the notation, R–X···R′, the halogen X acts as the halogen bond donor and R′ the electron donor such as N, O, S, or another halogen atom, acts as the halogen bond acceptor. Both halogen and hydrogen bonds are subsets of σ-hole bonding, and while there is still some argument about the relative roles of each contribution there is general consensus that these interactions are primarily electrostatic with contributions from polarization, dispersion, covalent, and steric effects. Halogen bonds are of comparable strengths to hydrogen bonds (5 kJ/mol (weak) – 180 kJ/mol (strong)), but they are more tunable and directional. Their strength is determined by the size of the σ-hole which is known to increase with size and polarizability of the halogen atom and electronegativity of R. Hence the strength of the halogen bond typically increases in the order F < Cl < Br < I. The increased directionality imparts more geometrical restrictions on halogen bonds over hydrogen bonds, increasing the possibility that building blocks can be brought into a certain architecture in a predictable way. The tunability and directionality of halogen bonding are therefore advantageous in the engineering of targeted solid-state structures. In addition, the amphipathic nature of the halogen atom which enables it to act as both halogen bond donor via the σ-hole and halogen bond acceptor via the electron rich area orthogonal to the σ-hole, can be manipulated to yield predetermined architectures. This orthogonal relationship was used by Vasylyeva et al. to model the assembly of peptide backbone mimics with halogenated aromatic compounds. Other examples in biological systems, supramolecular organic compounds and metal complexes are known. For example, the Cahill group has explored the use of halogen bonding interactions to promote the assembly of several molecular actinide complexes. However, the potential and limitations of halogen bonding as a structure directing force which can inform design principles in extended coordination polymers (CPs) and MOFs have not been assessed and must be further explored.

elements.content: To this end, we have chosen the rigid perhalogenated tetrabromoterephthalic acid ligand (H2TBrTA) which has the potential to form strong coordination bonds with metal ions through the carboxylate groups and the ability to form halogen···halogen interactions leading to high dimensional coordination polymers. A recent search of the Cambridge Structural Database (Version 5.39, August 2018) showed 88 metal–organic structures with TBrTA, 5 of which feature Br···Br interactions that were surprisingly not mentioned in the structural descriptions. In addition, only four contain lanthanide­(III) (Ln­(III)) ions, with one structure based on TBrTA only, as the others crystallize with various coligands.
elements.clean_text: To this end, we have chosen the rigid perhalogenated tetrabromoterephthalic acid ligand (H2TBrTA) which has the potential to form strong coordination bonds with metal ions through the carboxylate groups and the ability to form halogen⋅⋅⋅halogen interactions leading to high dimensional coordination polymers. A recent search of the Cambridge Structural Database (Version 5.39, August 2018) showed 88 metal-organic structures with TBrTA, 5 of which feature Br⋅⋅⋅Br interactions that were surprisingly not mentioned in the structural descriptions. In addition, only four contain lanthanide(III) (Ln(III)) ions, with one structure based on TBrTA only, as the others crystallize with various coligands.

elements.content: The unique coordination chemistry and electronic properties of Ln­(III) ions can generate CPs and MOFs with fascinating and unusual topologies, and desirable photoluminescent properties that can be exploited in the design of multifunctional materials with numerous applications in lighting (photonics), optical communications, biomedical devices, and catalysis. Lanthanide MOFs (Ln-MOFs) also provide an effective platform for chemical sensing due to a combination of the intrinsic porosity of MOFs and the inherent luminescent properties of lanthanide systems such as high optical purity, long luminescence lifetimes, and large Stokes shift. As such, luminescent Ln-MOF systems have demonstrated utility as fluorescent sensors for metal ions, anions, small organic molecules, and explosive nitroaromatic compounds. While many of these MOFs are based on derivatives of terephthalic acid including tetrafluoroterephthalic acid, there are no reports of sensing studies with Ln-TBrTA MOFs. In addition to this, examples of bifunctional Ln-MOF sensors which can rapidly, selectively, and sensitively detect both metals ions and nitroaromatic explosives are limited.

elements.content: Our group has been interested in the crystal engineering and luminescence behavior of Ln­(III)-containing materials for a long time. Herein we report the syntheses, structures, and luminescent sensing properties of two series of Ln-MOFs with TBrTA; series 1 consists of eight novel analogues of a known structural type with La–Dy and series 2 is a novel structural type with analogues from Ho–Lu. These compounds allow us to assess the role of X···X interactions in self-assembly and their evolution across the series of Ln­(III) ions.

These compounds allow us to assess the role of X⋅⋅⋅X interactions in self-assembly and their evolution across the series of Ln(III) ions.

elements.content: The LnCl3·xH2O (where Ln = La–Lu except Ce and Pm) salts were prepared by neutralizing the lanthanide oxides (≥99.9%, Aldrich) with reagent grade concentrated hydrochloric acid, followed by evaporation to near dryness. Ce­(NO3)3·6H2O (99.99%, Aldrich), sodium hydroxide (≥97.5%, British Drug House), tetrabromoterephthalic acid (97.7%, Aldrich) are commercially available and were used without further purification. Nonbleeding pH-indicator strips 0.0–6.0 and 4.0–7.0 were obtained from BDH VWR International Ltd. and EMD Chemicals Inc., respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

The LnCl3⋅xH2O (where Ln = La-Lu except Ce and Pm) salts were prepared by neutralizing the lanthanide oxides (≥99.9%, Aldrich) with reagent grade concentrated hydrochloric acid, followed by evaporation to near dryness. Ce(NO3)3⋅6H2O (99.99%, Aldrich), sodium hydroxide (≥97.5%, British Drug House), tetrabromoterephthalic acid (97.7%, Aldrich) are commercially available and were used without further purification. Nonbleeding pH-indicator strips 0.0-6.0 and 4.0-7.0 were obtained from BDH VWR International Ltd. and EMD Chemicals Inc., respectively.

elements.content: Infrared spectra (IR) were measured on a PerkinElmer Vector 22 FT-IR spectrophotometer (600–4000 cm–1, ATR). Simultaneous thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) and differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) were performed at the University of the West Indies, St. Augustine Campus on bulk samples encased in standard alumina crucibles (100 μL), from room temperature to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min–1 using a Setaram SETSYS Evolution system flushed with helium. Excitation and emission spectra were recorded at the University of the West Indies on a Yvon Jobin FluoroMax-2 spectrofluorometer via Datamax version 2.2 software. Slit widths were manipulated to simultaneously give the highest resolution and signal-to-noise ratio, and samples were sealed in 4 mm glass tubes for data collection. UV–vis absorption spectra were recorded on a Hewlett-Packard 8453 diode-array spectrophotometer from 190–1100 nm in a quartz cuvette with 1 cm path length at 25 °C. Baseline corrections were recorded before measurements using blank solvents.

elements.content: The same procedure was used in the synthesis of compounds 1–9. In a typical synthesis, solid H2TBrTA (1 mmol) was added to a warm solution of LnCl3·xH2O (8 mmol Ln3+) in 15 mL of water as it was being heated and stirred. NaOH solution (∼0.5 M) was added dropwise until pH 5.5–6.1. The reaction mixture was stirred for ∼5 min and then filtered into a warm conical flask which was covered with perforated Parafilm and placed on a sand bath at ∼90 °C. After a white thin layer formed at the bottom of the flask, the mixture was filtered once more in a conical flask which was covered with perforated Parafilm and returned to the sand bath. Three-dimensional (3D) elongated hexagonal prismatic crystals suitable for X-ray analyses were obtained after 2–5 days. Yields and IR frequencies for compounds can be seen in Table S2 of the Supporting Information.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Compounds 1-14 

General Syntheses of {Ln2(TBrTA)3(H2O)8⋅2H2O} n  [Ln = La (1) to Dy (9), except Pm] Compounds - Series 1 

The same procedure was used in the synthesis of compounds 1-9. In a typical synthesis, solid H2TBrTA (1 mmol) was added to a warm solution of LnCl3⋅xH2O (8 mmol Ln3+) in 15 mL of water as it was being heated and stirred. NaOH solution (~0.5 M) was added dropwise until pH 5.5-6.1. The reaction mixture was stirred for ~5 min and then filtered into a warm conical flask which was covered with perforated Parafilm and placed on a sand bath at ~90 °C. After a white thin layer formed at the bottom of the flask, the mixture was filtered once more in a conical flask which was covered with perforated Parafilm and returned to the sand bath. Three-dimensional (3D) elongated hexagonal prismatic crystals suitable for X-ray analyses were obtained after 2-5 days. Yields and IR frequencies for compounds can be seen in Table S2 of the Supporting Information.

elements.content: Compounds 10–14 are isostructural and were synthesized by a reaction procedure similar to that described for compounds 1–9, using the corresponding LnCl3·xH2O as the starting material. Yields and IR frequencies for compounds can be seen in Table S3 of the Supporting Information.
elements.clean_text:
General Syntheses of {[Ln3(TBrTA)6][Ln(H2O)8]⋅6H2O} n  [Ln = Ho (10) to Lu (14)] Compounds - Series 2 

Compounds 10-14 are isostructural and were synthesized by a reaction procedure similar to that described for compounds 1-9, using the corresponding LnCl3⋅xH2O as the starting material. Yields and IR frequencies for compounds can be seen in Table S3 of the Supporting Information.

elements.content: Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were obtained at the University of the West Indies on a Bruker D5005 powder diffractometer with Cu Κα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å) at 45 kV and 40 mA for compounds 1–14. The simulated powder patterns were calculated from single crystal X-ray diffraction data and processed by the free Mercury (version 3.9) program provided by the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (CCDC). Single crystal diffraction data for compounds 1–14 were collected at The George Washington University with 0.5° ω scans on a Bruker SMART diffractometer with APEXII CCD detector using Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation. The data were integrated using SAINT contained in the APEXII software suite, and absorption corrections were applied via SADABS. All structures were solved via intrinsic phasing using SHELXT (1, 2, 5, 7, 9–14) or via direct methods using SIR 92 (3, 4, 6, 8) and refined using SHELXL-2014 in the WinGX software suite. All non-hydrogen atoms were found in the difference Fourier maps and were refined anisotropically in all structures. The hydrogen atoms on coordinated and lattice water molecules were found in the Fourier maps and modeled in compounds 1–9 (except for 7, where hydrogens were not found on OW1, OW3, or OW4) and were not found or modeled on any water molecules in compounds 10–14. Additionally, DFIX commands were used on all five water molecules in compounds 4, 6, and 8, on OW1, OW4, and OW5 in 3, and on OW2 in compounds 5 and 9. PART commands were utilized to model two part atomic disorder for OW2A/OW2B in compounds 10–12 and 14 and for OW3A/OW3B in compound 13. SIMU, RIGU, and ISOR commands were also utilized along with the PART commands. Structural manipulations and analyses as well as molecular graphics were done with CrystalMaker and Mercury at the University of the West Indies. Topological analyses were carried out using ToposPro software. Crystal data and structure refinement details for compounds 1–14 are presented in Table S1, and selected bond lengths and bond angles are given in Table S4.

elements.content: Sensing studies were carried out by first dispersing 2 mg of compound 6 in 1.8 mL of ethanol by ultrasonication for 45 min. The luminescence intensity of the strongest Ln3+ transition was then recorded before and after rapid interaction with 0.2 mL of 1.0 × 10–2 M M­(Cl) x ethanol solution (Mx+ = Al3+, Fe3+, Cu2+, Co2+, Hg2+, Mg2+, Ni2+, Zn2+, and Mn2+) and 1.0 × 10–2 M nitrobenzene (NB), 1,3-dinitrobenzene (1,3-DNB), 1,3,5-trinitrobenzene (TNB), 3-nitrophenol (3-NTP), 4-nitrophenol (4-NTP), 2,4-dinitrophenol (2,4-DNP), 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP), 3,5-nitrobenzoic acid (3,5-DNTBA), 3-nitrobenzaldehyde (3-NBZAL), 3-nitroaniline (3-NTAN), 4-nitroaniline (4-NTAN), 2-nitrotoluene (2-NTT), phenol, and aniline (AN). The recyclable performance of compounds was investigated by recording the luminescence intensity before and after addition of 0.2 mL of 1.0 × 10–2 M analyte in ethanol followed by regeneration via centrifugation of the suspension after use and washing several times in ethanol.

Sensing Studies

Sensing studies were carried out by first dispersing 2 mg of compound 6 in 1.8 mL of ethanol by ultrasonication for 45 min. The luminescence intensity of the strongest Ln3+ transition was then recorded before and after rapid interaction with 0.2 mL of 1.0 × 10-2 M M(Cl) x  ethanol solution (Mx+ = Al3+, Fe3+, Cu2+, Co2+, Hg2+, Mg2+, Ni2+, Zn2+, and Mn2+) and 1.0 × 10-2 M nitrobenzene (NB), 1,3-dinitrobenzene (1,3-DNB), 1,3,5-trinitrobenzene (TNB), 3-nitrophenol (3-NTP), 4-nitrophenol (4-NTP), 2,4-dinitrophenol (2,4-DNP), 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP), 3,5-nitrobenzoic acid (3,5-DNTBA), 3-nitrobenzaldehyde (3-NBZAL), 3-nitroaniline (3-NTAN), 4-nitroaniline (4-NTAN), 2-nitrotoluene (2-NTT), phenol, and aniline (AN). The recyclable performance of compounds was investigated by recording the luminescence intensity before and after addition of 0.2 mL of 1.0 × 10-2 M analyte in ethanol followed by regeneration via centrifugation of the suspension after use and washing several times in ethanol.

elements.content: Compounds 1–14 can be formed under slow evaporation conditions on the benchtop or on a sand bath. Bench top evaporation can however result in long crystallization times (up to 3 weeks), and hence sand bath evaporation at ∼90 °C (2−5 days) was preferred. The size of the lanthanide­(III) ion (lanthanide contraction) influenced compound formation as two series of compounds were formed using TBrTA. A solution pH of 5.5–6.1 was necessary to promote structure formation; below pH = 5 the ligand crystallized out of solution due to the protonation of the carboxyl groups, while at pH > 7 only amorphous solid was formed.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis

Compounds 1-14 can be formed under slow evaporation conditions on the benchtop or on a sand bath. Bench top evaporation can however result in long crystallization times (up to 3 weeks), and hence sand bath evaporation at ~90 °C (2-5 days) was preferred. The size of the lanthanide(III) ion (lanthanide contraction) influenced compound formation as two series of compounds were formed using TBrTA. A solution pH of 5.5-6.1 was necessary to promote structure formation; below pH = 5 the ligand crystallized out of solution due to the protonation of the carboxyl groups, while at pH > 7 only amorphous solid was formed.

elements.content: X-ray crystallographic analysis reveals that compounds 1–9 are isomorphous crystallizing in the low symmetry space group P1̅. The Nd­(III) analogue was previously reported by Wei et al., but here we report the lanthanide series from La­(III) to Dy­(III). To the best of our knowledge, the single crystal structures of the other frameworks in this series are reported here for the first time. The {Eu2(TBrTA)3­(H2O)8­·2H2O} n (6) structure is representative and is discussed herein. Each asymmetric unit consists of one crystallographically independent Eu3+ ion, one and a half deprotonated TBrTA ligands, and five water molecules (four ligating and one lattice) (a). Each Eu3+ ion is octacoordinate with three carboxylate oxygens from three independent μ3-κO:κO:κO TBrTA ligands, one carboxylate oxygen from an independent μ2-κO:κO TBrTA ligand, and four oxygens from bound water molecules. This forms a highly distorted EuO8 square antiprism (D 4d ) geometry around the central lanthanide ion with Eu–O bond lengths between 2.298(3) and 2.534(3) Å, which is comparable to Ln–O bond distances in previously reported Ln-terephthalate CPs (Table S4). Neighboring Eu3+ ions bridge through two carboxylate groups in the μ2-κO:κO coordination mode from two independent μ3-κO:κO:κO TBrTA ligands to yield a [Eu2(COO)2] dinuclear unit with Eu–Eu separation of 5.314 Å (b). Adjacent dinuclear units are connected into a chain structure by two parallel displaced μ3-κO:κO:κO TBrTA ligands which are related by an inversion center. The chains grow in one dimension along the b-direction and feature π–π stacking interactions between the bridging TBrTA rings (centroid–centroid distance = 4.038 Å). An infinite 2D sheet is formed along the bc-plane as μ2-κO:κO TBrTA ligands connect 1D chains along the c-axis (c).

Structural Description of {Ln2(TBrTA)3(H2O)8⋅2H2O} n  [Ln = La-Dy (1-9, respectively)] - Series 1

X-ray crystallographic analysis reveals that compounds 1-9 are isomorphous crystallizing in the low symmetry space group P1̅. The Nd(III) analogue was previously reported by Wei et al., but here we report the lanthanide series from La(III) to Dy(III). To the best of our knowledge, the single crystal structures of the other frameworks in this series are reported here for the first time. The {Eu2(TBrTA)3(H2O)8⋅2H2O} n  (6) structure is representative and is discussed herein. Each asymmetric unit consists of one crystallographically independent Eu3+ ion, one and a half deprotonated TBrTA ligands, and five water molecules (four ligating and one lattice) (a). Each Eu3+ ion is octacoordinate with three carboxylate oxygens from three independent μ3-κO:κO:κO TBrTA ligands, one carboxylate oxygen from an independent μ2-κO:κO TBrTA ligand, and four oxygens from bound water molecules. This forms a highly distorted EuO8 square antiprism (D 4d ) geometry around the central lanthanide ion with Eu-O bond lengths between 2.298(3) and 2.534(3) Å, which is comparable to Ln-O bond distances in previously reported Ln-terephthalate CPs (Table S4). Neighboring Eu3+ ions bridge through two carboxylate groups in the μ2-κO:κO coordination mode from two independent μ3-κO:κO:κO TBrTA ligands to yield a [Eu2(COO)2] dinuclear unit with Eu-Eu separation of 5.314 Å (b). Adjacent dinuclear units are connected into a chain structure by two parallel displaced μ3-κO:κO:κO TBrTA ligands which are related by an inversion center. The chains grow in one dimension along the b-direction and feature π-π stacking interactions between the bridging TBrTA rings (centroid-centroid distance = 4.038 Å). An infinite 2D sheet is formed along the bc-plane as μ2-κO:κO TBrTA ligands connect 1D chains along the c-axis (c).

elements.content: The 2D sheet of 6 is further stabilized by intermolecular Br···Br halogen interactions. R–X···X–R contacts can adopt either type I, type II, or quasi-type I/type II geometries (). Type I interactions (symmetrical interactions where θ1 ≈ θ2) arise from close packing arrangements but may be electrostatically attractive when θ = 140–160°. Type II interactions (bent interactions where θ1 ≈ 180° and θ2 ≈ 90°) on the other hand are always electrostatically attractive and are classified as halogen bonds since they are formed from the pairing of the electrophilic area (σ-hole) on one halogen atom and the nucleophilic area on the other. Quasi-type I/type II are intermediary contacts with 15° ≤ |θ1 – θ2| ≤ 30°. The relative strength of halogen···halogen supramolecular interactions can be determined by measuring the X···X interatomic distance and expressing it as a percentage of the sum of their van der Waals (vdW) radii. The 2D layers in 6 feature type II Br···Br interactions between Br3 of a μ3-κO:κO:κO TBrTA and Br5 of a μ2-κO:κO TBrTA; Br···Br interaction distance = 3.423 Å (92.5% sum of the vdW radii); θ1 (∠C11–Br5···Br3) = 172.05°, and θ2 (∠C6–Br3···Br5) = 79.31° (c). There is a 0.9% reduction in observed Br3···Br5 interaction distances in series 1, which suggests an overall increase in the relative strength of the halogen bond as the ionic radii of the Ln­(III) is decreased (lanthanide contraction effects, ).

Adjacent 2D layers stack in a staggered way to form a 3D supramolecular structure through two additional intermolecular Br···Br interactions, six O–H···O and two O–H···Br hydrogen bonding interactions (d). The first Br···Br interaction is type I between Br1 of a μ3-κO:κO:κO TBrTA ligand and Br3 of another μ3-κO:κO:κO TBrTA ligand in an adjacent sheet; Br1···Br3 interaction distance = 3.425 Å (92.5% sum of the vdW), θ1 (∠C3–Br1···Br3) = 130.98° and θ2 (∠C6–Br3···Br1) = 127.44° with θ1–θ2 = 3.54°. The second Br···Br interaction is between Br3 of a μ3-κO:κO:κO TBrTA and Br4 of a μ2-κO:κO TBrTA in an adjacent sheet; Br3···Br4 interaction distance = 3.605 Å (sum of the 97.4% vdW radii); θ1 (∠C6–Br3···Br4) = 139.20°; and θ2 (∠C7–Br4···Br3) = 109.25° and is classified as a quasi-type I/type II interaction with θ1–θ2 = 29.95°. There is a decrease in the Br3···Br4 interaction distance as the atomic number of the Ln­(III) increases accompanied by a reduction in the minimum interlayer distance from 6.736 Å in La­(III) to 6.699 Å in Dy­(III). This is possibly due to a resultant increase in the strength of hydrogen bonding interactions between water molecules trapped between the layers (OW5) and both ligated framework water molecules (OW3 and OW4) and framework oxygens (O4) leading to a closer approach of the layers (La­(III): OW4–HW4B···OW5 = 1.977 Å, OW3–HW3A···OW5 = 1.883 Å, OW5–HW5B···O4 = 2.219 Å, OW5–HW5A···O4 = 1.909 Å ; Dy­(III): OW4–HW4B···OW5 = 1.853 Å; OW3–HW3A···OW5 = 1.954 Å, OW5–HW5B···O4 = 2.151 Å, OW5–HW5A···O4 = 2.116 Å).

elements.content: O–H···O hydrogen bonding interactions also occur between framework oxygens (which serve as hydrogen bond acceptors (A)), and ligated water molecules (which serve as hydrogen bond donors (D)) (D···A distance = 2.947 Å, ∠D–H···A = 176.14°). Two O–H···Br hydrogen bonding interactions which are uncommon supramolecular synthons are observed between ligated water molecules (OW1 and OW3, which serve as hydrogen bond donors) and bromine atoms (Br1 of μ3-κO:κO:κO TBrTA ligands which serve as H-bond acceptors) (OW1···Br1 distance = 3.571 Å, ∠OW1–H50···Br1 = 148° and OW3···Br1 distance = 3.522 Å, ∠OW3–H55···Br1 = 132°). Hydrogen bonding interactions are listed in Table S10 of the Supporting Information. Cavities of dimensions 3.528 × 7.495 Å (atom to atom separation) are observed upon removal of water molecules, leading to solvent accessible voids of 19 Å3 (1.7% of unit cell volume) calculated using Platon.

elements.content: Topological analysis facilitates a greater understanding of the intricate and often complex structures of CPs and MOFs through a simplification of their connectivity into simple node and linker reference networks. Using the ToposPro software, it is possible to identify the underlying network topology by the application of several structure simplification procedures such as the elimination of terminal ligands and the contraction of complicated groups into centers of mass. By using a standard simplification method, each Eu­(III) center in 6 is defined as a 4-connected (4-c) node, while the μ3-κO:κO:κO and μ2-κO:κO TBrTAs are viewed as 3-c and linear linkers, respectively. This leads to a 2-nodal 3,4-c 2D network with the bey topology and the corresponding {4^2.6^3.8}{4^2.6} point symbol (e). The topology can also be deconstructed by using a cluster simplification method where finite [Eu2(COO)6(H2O)8] secondary building units (SBUs) are consolidated into a center of mass forming a 4-c node and TBrTA ligands are linear linkers resulting in a uninodal 4-c 2D network with point symbol {4^4.6^2} and sql [Shubnikov tetragonal plane network] topological type (f).

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray analysis reveals that compounds 10–14 are isomorphous crystallizing in the space group R3̅. The compounds feature a novel 3D anionic framework consisting of polymeric [Ln3(TBrTA)6]3– units that are charge balanced by cationic [Ln­(H2O)8]3+ moieties in the lattice. The crystal structure of 10 is representative and is discussed herein. The asymmetric unit consists of three crystallographically independent Ho3+ ions (Ho1, Ho2 in the framework, and Ho3 in the lattice), one deprotonated μ3-κO:κO:κO TBrTA ligand, as well as two bound and two lattice water molecules (a). The Ho1 center is hexacoordinated by carboxyl oxygen atoms (O1) from six different μ3-κO:κO:κO TBrTA ligands forming an octahedral geometry with Ho–O bond distances of 2.217(4) Å. The Ho2 center is also hexacoordinated in an octahedral geometry with carboxyl oxygens (O2 and O3) from six independent TBrTA ligands and Ho–O bond distances of (Ho2–O3) 2.181(4) and (Ho2–O2) 2.277(4) Å. The central Ho1 ion is connected to two Ho2 ions by six carboxylate groups of TBrTA ligands forming a unique linear trinuclear [(Ho2–Ho1–Ho2)­(COO)6]3– SBU that runs along the c-axis (b). The linear [Ho3(COO)6]3– SBUs are locally supported by 12 μ3-κO:κO:κO TBrTA ligands (b) forming a 3D anionic framework (d–e). The overall structure is charge balanced by disordered [Ho­(H2O)8]3+ cations in the pores, which are sandwiched between uncoordinated carboxylate oxygens of the trinuclear [Ho3(TBrTA)12]3– clusters. The most outstanding feature of this compound is however the unprecedented 3D “Star of David” (H2O)12 clusters which encapsulate the [Ho­(H2O)8]3+ cations forming metallo-aqua hydrate clathrates (c). Within these clusters the O–Oavg distance is 3.42 Å, which is longer than the O–Oavg distances of 2.76 and 2.85 Å reported for hexagonal ice and liquid water, respectively. The Ho­(III) is in distorted D 4d symmetry with Ho3–O distances from 2.187–2.286 Å. The metallo-aqua hydrate clathrate is sandwiched between six free carboxylate oxygens of TBrTA ligands. There are significant hydrogen bonding interactions between water molecules of the clathrate cage and framework carboxylic oxygens (O4–OW1 = 2.578 Å, O4–OW2A = 2.777 Å, O4–Ow2A = 3.058 Å) as well as between disordered water molecules on the octa aqua Ho­(III) cation and water molecules in the clathrate cage (OW2B–OW1 = 2.431 Å, Ow2B–OW2A = 1.583 Å, OW2A–OW3 = 1.768 Å).

elements.content: Water clusters have attracted much attention from experimentalists and theorists since they are important models for studying biological systems and bulk water. In this context, numerous examples, from tetramers to hexamers, dodecamers and (H2O)45, the largest water cluster known, have been reported. Indeed, water clusters are known to be trapped in the pores of MOFs and direct the assembly of various supramolecular architectures. However, to the best of our knowledge this represents only the second example in which (H2O) n clusters trapped within a MOF further encapsulate a metal hydrate species. Furthermore, this is the only such system where n > 10 and the way in which these water molecules respond to this unique environment could provide critical insights to bridge the current disconnect between theoretical and experimental studies on water clusters in confined systems. When Platon was used to remove water clusters from the cavities (maximum diameter - 7.526 Å), solvent accessible voids of 230 Å3 or 3.7% of unit cell volume were revealed.

Similar to series 1, as the size of the lanthanide ion decreases, there is a noticeable increase in the strength of type II X···X interactions.

elements.content: Topological analysis of series 2 reveals further information on the assembly of structural units in the framework. Each Ho3 SBU is locally supported by 12 μ3-κO:κO:κO TBrTA ligands, pairs of which connect to a single neighboring SBU. Each pair is treated as a linear linker directly connecting each Ho3 SBU to 6 neighbors, forming a 3D 6-connected uninodal network with point symbol {4^12.6^3} and a pcu alpha-po primitive cubic network topology (f).

elements.content: The increase in ionic potential (q/r) across the lanthanide series is known to significantly impact the structure and give some diversity to lanthanide MOFs and CPs. The subsequent decrease in Ln­(III) size, or lanthanide contraction, plays a role in the evolution of supramolecular interactions such as those in chlorobenzoic, terpyridine, and phenanthroline complexes reported by Carter et al. However, there has been no attempt to correlate ionic radii with supramolecular interactions in extended structures like MOFs and CPs.
elements.clean_text:
Evolution of Supramolecular Interactions in Series 1 and 2 

The increase in ionic potential (q/r) across the lanthanide series is known to significantly impact the structure and give some diversity to lanthanide MOFs and CPs. The subsequent decrease in Ln(III) size, or lanthanide contraction, plays a role in the evolution of supramolecular interactions such as those in chlorobenzoic, terpyridine, and phenanthroline complexes reported by Carter et al. However, there has been no attempt to correlate ionic radii with supramolecular interactions in extended structures like MOFs and CPs.

elements.content: With the reaction conditions and reagents the same, the effect of lanthanide size was isolated during this study and gave rise to series 1 for La–Dy and series 2 for Ho–Lu. The structure changes from a 2D MOF assembled from dinuclear SBUs in the former, to a 3D MOF featuring trinuclear SBUs in the latter. The larger Ln­(III) ions of series 1 are eight coordinate, bonding to four water molecules and four carboxyl oxygens from both μ3-κO:κO:κO and μ2-κO:κO TBrTAs. On the other hand, the smaller lanthanides of series 2 exclude water molecules from the primary coordination sphere, instead trapping them as water clusters in the pores of the MOF. As expected, the coordination number decreases to six, and interestingly, the ligand adopts only the μ3-κO:κO:κO coordination mode.

The structure changes from a 2D MOF assembled from dinuclear SBUs in the former, to a 3D MOF featuring trinuclear SBUs in the latter. The larger Ln(III) ions of series 1 are eight coordinate, bonding to four water molecules and four carboxyl oxygens from both μ3-κO:κO:κO and μ2-κO:κO TBrTAs. On the other hand, the smaller lanthanides of series 2 exclude water molecules from the primary coordination sphere, instead trapping them as water clusters in the pores of the MOF. As expected, the coordination number decreases to six, and interestingly, the ligand adopts only the μ3-κO:κO:κO coordination mode.

elements.content: Supramolecular interactions also evolve with the lanthanide contraction; series 1 features Br···Br, Br···O, π–π and hydrogen bonding interactions, while in series 2 only Br···Br and hydrogen bonding interactions are involved in the self-assembly. More interestingly, the nature of the Br···Br interactions progresses from type I, type II, and quasi type1/type II in series 1 to only type II in series 2 (). There is an overall decrease in type II Br···Br interaction distance (0.7% in series 1 and 1.4% in series 2) as the size of the lanthanide ion decreases, possibly due to an increase in charge density which facilitates a closer approach of bromine atoms. A plot of Br···Br distance versus f-element electronic configuration for both series 1 and 2 shows a decrease that is best modeled by a quadratic decay (). This parallels findings of Quadrelli, Ibers, Raymond, and Cahill et al. who found that a quadratic equation best describes the lanthanide contraction based on Ln–X (X = O, N, Te) distances. To the best of our knowledge, this represents the first example in which the change in strength of X···X interactions is correlated to the lanthanide contraction. Traditionally, the strength of X···X interactions has been systematically tuned by manipulating the halogen atom, but the lanthanide contraction presents a new design strategy that could be exploited to tune the strengths of halogen bonds in CPs and MOFs.

elements.content: To study the thermal stability of the compounds, thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) and differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) analyses were performed from 25–800 °C on representative samples from each series which include compounds 4 and 14. Compound 4 records its first weight loss between 100–150 °C, which corresponds to the loss of eight coordinated and two uncoordinated water molecules (9.6% cf. theoretical 9.4%) and is accompanied by an endothermic event in the DSC signal, as expected (Figure S3). There is no further weight loss until about 400 °C where there is a significant decrease of ∼30% from 430–500 °C due to the onset of framework decomposition which continues up to 800 °C. This is accompanied by an exothermic event in the DSC signal. Compound 14 depicts a subtle change in mass from 40–100 °C which is endothermic in the DSC signal and corresponds to the loss of approximately one uncoordinated water molecule (0.5% cf. theoretical 0.5%) (Figure S3). The structure remains stable until there is a second dehydration event between 170–300 °C which corresponds to the mass loss of the remaining uncoordinated and coordinated water molecules (7.2% cf. theoretical 6.6%). The framework starts to break down shortly after as seen by the exothermic event in the DSC signal from about 350–500 °C, which continues up to 800 °C. Simulated (Sim) and as-synthesized (AS) PXRD patterns presented in Figures S4 and S5 correspond well with each other and indicate the phase purity of all samples.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Properties and PXRD Patterns

To study the thermal stability of the compounds, thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) and differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) analyses were performed from 25-800 °C on representative samples from each series which include compounds 4 and 14. Compound 4 records its first weight loss between 100-150 °C, which corresponds to the loss of eight coordinated and two uncoordinated water molecules (9.6% cf. theoretical 9.4%) and is accompanied by an endothermic event in the DSC signal, as expected (Figure S3). There is no further weight loss until about 400 °C where there is a significant decrease of ~30% from 430-500 °C due to the onset of framework decomposition which continues up to 800 °C. This is accompanied by an exothermic event in the DSC signal. Compound 14 depicts a subtle change in mass from 40-100 °C which is endothermic in the DSC signal and corresponds to the loss of approximately one uncoordinated water molecule (0.5% cf. theoretical 0.5%) (Figure S3). The structure remains stable until there is a second dehydration event between 170-300 °C which corresponds to the mass loss of the remaining uncoordinated and coordinated water molecules (7.2% cf. theoretical 6.6%). The framework starts to break down shortly after as seen by the exothermic event in the DSC signal from about 350-500 °C, which continues up to 800 °C. Simulated (Sim) and as-synthesized (AS) PXRD patterns presented in Figures S4 and S5 correspond well with each other and indicate the phase purity of all samples.

elements.content: The solid state photoluminescent spectra of the Eu3+ and Tb3+ analogues of series 1 were obtained at room temperature. Indiscriminate excitation of {Eu2(TBrTA)3­(H2O)8­·2H2O} n (6) at 350 nm produces bright red emission which features peaks characteristic of Eu­(III) luminescence (a). The emission peaks at 576.5, 586–590.5, 611, 650, and 691–696 are assigned to 5D0 → 7F J transitions (J = 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, respectively) of Eu3+ ions. The spectrum of 6 is dominated by the electric dipole 5D0 → 7F2 transition with the magnetic dipole 5D0 → 7F1 being more intense than the 5D0 → 7F4 transition and with the 5D0 → 7F0 characteristic transition of Eu­(III) also present. This profile is unusual for Eu3+ in D 4d symmetry, where 5D0 → 7F2 and 5D0 → 7F0 are forbidden, and has been attributed to a lowering of the overall crystal field experienced by the Eu3+ ion as well as quadrupolar contributions to 5D0 → 7F2. The absence of ligand-centered emission suggests that TBrTA is an efficient sensitizer of Eu3+ (5D0) emission. Accordingly, the excitation spectrum, acquired by monitoring the Eu3+ (5D0 → 7F2) at 611 nm shows a broad ligand excitation band from 300–400 nm as well as direct Eu3+ (5D4 ← 7F0), 5G2–6(n) ← 7F0, 5L6 ← 7F0, 5D3 ← 7F1, 5D2 ← 7F0, 5D1 ← 7F0 and 5D1 ← 7F1 transitions.
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescent Properties

The solid state photoluminescent spectra of the Eu3+ and Tb3+ analogues of series 1 were obtained at room temperature. Indiscriminate excitation of {Eu2(TBrTA)3(H2O)8⋅2H2O} n  (6) at 350 nm produces bright red emission which features peaks characteristic of Eu(III) luminescence (a). The emission peaks at 576.5, 586-590.5, 611, 650, and 691-696 are assigned to 5D0 → 7F J  transitions (J = 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, respectively) of Eu3+ ions. The spectrum of 6 is dominated by the electric dipole 5D0 → 7F2 transition with the magnetic dipole 5D0 → 7F1 being more intense than the 5D0 → 7F4 transition and with the 5D0 → 7F0 characteristic transition of Eu(III) also present. This profile is unusual for Eu3+ in D 4d  symmetry, where 5D0 → 7F2 and 5D0 → 7F0 are forbidden, and has been attributed to a lowering of the overall crystal field experienced by the Eu3+ ion as well as quadrupolar contributions to 5D0 → 7F2. The absence of ligand-centered emission suggests that TBrTA is an efficient sensitizer of Eu3+ (5D0) emission. Accordingly, the excitation spectrum, acquired by monitoring the Eu3+ (5D0 → 7F2) at 611 nm shows a broad ligand excitation band from 300-400 nm as well as direct Eu3+ (5D4 ← 7F0), 5G2-6(n) ← 7F0, 5L6 ← 7F0, 5D3 ← 7F1, 5D2 ← 7F0, 5D1 ← 7F0 and 5D1 ← 7F1 transitions.

elements.content: The {Tb2(TBrTA)3­(H2O)8­·2H2O} n (8) analogue displays strong green emission upon excitation of the ligand at 305 nm (b). The spectrum shows narrow peaks at 488, 543.5, 584, and 620 nm corresponding to 5D4 → 7FJ transitions (J = 6, 5, 4, 3, respectively) of Tb3+. The absence of ligand-centered emission suggests that TBrTA is also a good sensitizer of Tb3+ (5D4) luminescence via the “antenna effect”. The excitation spectrum obtained by monitoring the 5D4 → 7F5 emission at 543.5 nm features broad ligand-based excitation with superimposed transitions from the 7F6 ground level. This indicates that there are contributions from the ligand as well as excited states of Tb3+ to this emission.

elements.content: Luminescent Ln-MOFs have been increasingly used in recent times as probes for the detection of small molecules, metal ions, and explosive nitroaromatic compounds (NACs) exhibiting high sensitivity and selectivity. Due to the high emission intensity of compound 6 (Eu3+), we sought to investigate its potential as a sensor for metal ions and NACs. We first investigated the luminescence intensity of 6 (2 mg) in various commonly used solvents (2 mL) to identify the most suitable solvent. As seen in a, the emission intensity of 6 is strongest in ethanol compared to other solvents such as methanol, water, acetone, acetonitrile, N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), dichloromethane (DCM), dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), cyclohexane, benzene, and toluene. Subsequently, the potential of ethanol suspensions of 6 (6-EtOH) to sense Al3+, Fe3+, Cu2+, Co2+, Hg2+, Mg2+, Ni2+, Zn2+, and Mn2+ metal ions was assessed by monitoring the Eu3+ (5D0 → 7F2) transition at 610 nm (λex = 310 nm). The extent of quenching of 5D0 → 7F2 was calculated by using : quenching efficiency = ( I 0 − I ) / I 0 × 100 % where I 0 and I are the luminescence intensities of 6-EtOH before and after interaction with metal ions, respectively. As shown in b the luminescence emission of 6-EtOH is most significantly quenched upon interaction with Fe3+ ions (87%) and Cu2+ ions (75%), while moderate quenching is observed for Co2+ and Al3+, negligible effects for Mn2+ and Ni2+ cations and a slight luminescent enhancement is seen for Hg2+, Mg2+, and Zn2+ cations. To gain a greater understanding of the luminescence response of 6 to Fe3+ and Cu2+ ions, luminescence titrations were conducted, in which incremental amounts of these analytes were added to suspensions of 6-EtOH (c–d). As expected, the luminescence intensity decreases with increasing concentration of analytes. The fluorescence quenching efficiency can be quantitatively explained by the Stern–Volmer (S–V) : ( I 0 / I ) = K SV [ Q ] + 1 where K SV is the Stern–Volmer constant/quenching effect coefficient (M–1) and [Q] is the molar concentration of the quencher. The Stern–Volmer plot for Fe3+ and Cu2+ ions is nearly linear at low concentrations (R 2 = 0.9891 for Fe3+ and 0.9893 for Cu2+) but deviate from linearity at high concentrations, which indicates that the quenching mechanism may feature both dynamic and static quenching processes or competitive absorption (i.e., inner filter effects) (e–f). The K SV values obtained at low concentrations were determined to be 6742.4 M–1 and 4612.0 M–1 for Fe3+ and Cu2+ respectively. These are comparable to K SV values in numerous studies which report CPs and MOFs as highly sensitive detectors for metal ions and demonstrate the high sensitivity of 6-EtOH toward Fe3+ and Cu2+. The limit of detection (LOD), calculated from the slope and standard error of the fitting lines (LOD = 3σ/K SV; σ = standard error of slope), is 6.79 × 10–5 mol/L (3.79 ppm) for Fe3+ and 7.52 × 10–5 mol/L (4.78 ppm) for Cu2+.

elements.content: We also investigated the ability of 6-EtOH to selectively detect Fe3+ and Cu2+ ions in the presence of various interfering Mx+ ions since they tend to coexist in environmental and biological systems. As shown in a–b, Eu3+ (5D0 → 7F2) emission from 6-EtOH is only significantly quenched upon introduction of Fe3+ and Cu2+ ions even in the presence of a wide array of metal ions. This demonstrates the high selectivity of 6-EtOH for the detection of Fe3+ and Cu2+ ions.

elements.content: To gain a deeper understanding of the mechanism of luminescence quenching of 6-EtOH by Fe3+ and Cu2+, we carried out further investigations. PXRD scans suggest that the structure remains the same even after addition of large amounts of Fe3+ and Cu2+ (Figure S6), and FT-IR spectra show no indication of metal ion interaction with the framework as the broad, strong, CO absorption band remains unchanged in the 1640–1560 cm–1 region (Figure S7). These rule out the possibility of static quenching since it would require complex formation that would very likely involve interaction of the Fe3+ and Cu2+ with the carboxylates in the framework.
elements.clean_text:
Mechanism of Luminescence Quenching

To gain a deeper understanding of the mechanism of luminescence quenching of 6-EtOH by Fe3+ and Cu2+, we carried out further investigations. PXRD scans suggest that the structure remains the same even after addition of large amounts of Fe3+ and Cu2+ (Figure S6), and FT-IR spectra show no indication of metal ion interaction with the framework as the broad, strong, CO absorption band remains unchanged in the 1640-1560 cm-1 region (Figure S7). These rule out the possibility of static quenching since it would require complex formation that would very likely involve interaction of the Fe3+ and Cu2+ with the carboxylates in the framework.

elements.content: Recyclability studies gave further insight into the nature of the quenching interaction. Recyclable fluorescent probes are more extensively employed for practical applications due to their cost-effective nature. Fast and simple regeneration methods are important to the recyclable performance of sensors; hence we sought to assess the recyclable performance of 6 toward Fe3+ and Cu2+ sensing. A typical run of the recyclability experiments was carried out by recording the luminescence intensity of Eu3+ (5D0 → 7F2) in 6-EtOH before and after addition of the analyte solution and regeneration by washing and centrifuging several times in ethanol. The initial fluorescence intensity is retained after five cycles (c–d), and the PXRD profiles of the recycled 6 are consistent with both the simulated and as-synthesized PXRD patterns (Figure S6). Together these results point to a fast, simple, and high recyclability performance of 6-EtOH in the detection of Fe3+ and Cu2+ and reveal that its interaction with these metal ions is weak. Hence the mechanism of luminescence quenching would not involve cation exchange, framework collapse, or static processes.

elements.content: Figure S8 highlights that there is no overlap between emission of the donor (Eu3+) and the absorbance of the acceptor (M x+) ions. Therefore, quenching of Eu3+ (5D0 → 7F2) in 6-EtOH by M x+ ions, including Fe3+ and Cu2+, does not proceed via an energy transfer pathway. Interestingly though, there is a stronger absorbance of Fe3+ and Cu2+ at λex = 310 nm compared to all other Mx+ ions. Therefore, in the presence of Fe3+ and Cu2+ competitive absorption of excitation energy likely contributes to the reduction in intensity of Eu3+ (5D0 → 7F2) in 6-EtOH. Fe3+ and Cu2+ have an inner filter effect on the emission of 6-EtOH, absorbing some of the incident excitation energy available to the TBrTA, thereby decreasing the efficiency of the antennae effect and ultimately the intensity of Eu3+ emission. Competitive absorption of excitation energy has been proposed in several studies as a possible pathway for the luminescence quenching of Ln­(III) ions by Fe3+ and Cu2+ in Ln-MOFs, and this argument is corroborated herein by the behavior of Ni2+ and Mn2+ where zero absorbance at λex = 310 nm results in negligible quenching.

Competitive absorption of excitation energy has been proposed in several studies as a possible pathway for the luminescence quenching of Ln(III) ions by Fe3+ and Cu2+ in Ln-MOFs, and this argument is corroborated herein by the behavior of Ni2+ and Mn2+ where zero absorbance at λex = 310 nm results in negligible quenching.

elements.content: The rapid and sensitive detection of explosive nitroaromatic compounds (NACs) is of importance in homeland security, environmental safety, and human health due to the detrimental effects of these compounds. In light of this, we explored the potential of 6-EtOH to sense NACs by monitoring the intensity of Eu3+ (5D0 → 7F2) transition before and after addition of nitrobenzene (NB), 1,3-dinitrobenzene (1,3-DNB), 1,3,5-trinitrobenzene (TNB), 3-nitrophenol (3-NTP), 4-nitrophenol (4-NTP), 2,4-dinitrophenol (2,4-DNP), 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP), 3,5-nitrobenzoic acid (3,5-DNTBA), 3-nitrobenzaldehyde (3-NBZAL), 3-nitroaniline (3-NTAN), 4-nitroaniline (4-NTAN), and 2-nitrotoluene (2-NTT). Studies were also carried out with phenol and aniline (AN) to comparatively assess the effect of the nitro group on the quenching efficiency of the analyte. Phenol presents a weak enhancing effect on the Eu3+ (5D0 → 7F2) emission of 6-EtOH, but all other aromatic compounds quenched the emission by varying degrees (). The order of quenching efficiency was 2,4-DNP > 4-NTP > TNP > 4-NTAN > 3-NTP > 2-NTT > 1,3-DNB > 3-NTAN > aniline > 3,5-DNTBA > TNB > 3-NBZAL > NB > phenol. This deviates slightly from the titration experiments which yielded the highest K SV for 4-NTP (11037.7 M–1) followed by 2,4-DNP (8378.8 M–1) and TNP (7320.1 M–1) (). The discrepancy may arise due to greater interaction of 4-NTP with 6-EtOH upon incremental addition during the titrations, resulting in a more accurate representation of the luminescence quenching behavior. Incremental addition of 4-NTP, 2,4-DNP, and TNP to 6-EtOH results in a progressive reduction in luminescence intensity (). The calculated LOD is 1.70 × 10–5 mol/L (2.37 ppm) for 4-NTP, 4.31 × 10–5 mol/L (7.94 ppm) for 2,4-DNP, and 7.46 × 10–5 mol/L (17.10 ppm) for TNP which are comparable to other reported MOF structures used for the detection of NACs. The Stern–Volmer plots for 4-NTP and 2,4-DNP are linear from low to high concentrations, suggesting that dynamic or static processes may contribute to the quenching of Eu3+ (5D0 → 7F2) emission. The Stern–Volmer plot for TNP is linear at low concentrations but deviates from linearity at higher concentrations with an upward curvature, which suggests that static and dynamic quenching processes may be acting simultaneously or there may be competitive absorption which leads to an inner filter effect. UV–vis absorption spectra of the analytes in ethanol show strong overlap between the excitation spectrum of 6 and the absorption spectra of 4-NTP, 2,4-DNP, TNP, and 4-NTAN, suggesting that there is competitive absorption for the excitation energy at 310 nm (Figure S9). Further comparison of phenol and aniline with their nitro congeners show that the presence of the nitro group and its location at the para- position enhances the quenching efficiency. Luminescence quenching of Ln-MOFs by NACs is known to involve photoinduced electron transfer from the conduction band of the MOF to LUMOs of the electron deficient nitroaromatic analyte. In addition, disruption of the supramolecular structure of the MOF by electrostatic forces such as π–π and hydrogen bonding interactions can also lead to quenching. IR data of compound 6 immersed in the NACs show that the structure remains the same, but a broadening of the peaks indicate that there may be electrostatic interactions of the NACs with the framework (Figure S10). Recyclability studies carried out with 4-NTP, 2,4-DNP, and TNP reveal that the initial luminescence intensity is not significantly affected even after five sensing-recovery cycles; hence, 6-EtOH is a highly regenerative probe for the detection of nitroaromatic compounds (Figure S11). Although further studies, including theoretical considerations and lifetime measurements, are needed to better understand quenching in these systems, competitive absorption, photoinduced electron transfer, and electrostatic processes likely play a significant role in the sensing of NACs by 6-EtOH.

elements.content: This study reports the synthesis, characterization, and potential sensing applications of novel lanthanide MOFs based on tetrabromoterephthalic acid. Fourteen compounds, which constitute two series, were synthesized under slow evaporation conditions. Series 1, formed with the larger lanthanides, La­(III)–Dy­(III), is a 2D structure comprising discrete binuclear Ln-carboxylate SBUs that assemble into a sql network. Series 2 forms with Ho­(III)–Lu­(III) and is a unique 3D anionic framework with linear trinuclear Ln-carboxylate SBUs arranged in a pcu network topology. The framework is charge balanced by [Ln­(H2O)8]3+ cations in the pores which are further encapsulated in an unprecedented 3D (H2O)12 “Star of David” dodecamer water cluster. Changing the size of the lanthanide ions changes the coordination mode of the ligand from μ3- and μ2-bridging monodentate in series 1 to only μ3-bridging monodentate in series 2 and limits the supramolecular interactions in series 2 to only Br···Br and hydrogen bonding. Furthermore, the Br···Br interactions evolve from types I, II and quasi-type I/II in series 1 to type II in series 2. The strength of type II interactions increases with decreasing size of the lanthanide­(III) ion for both series 1 and 2. These results show that Br···Br interactions can be tuned by exploiting the lanthanide contraction, and these interactions can in turn be manipulated to yield Ln-MOFs whose structures and functions are predesigned and targeted. Photoluminescent studies show that TBrTA is an efficient sensitizer of both Eu3+(5D0) and Tb3+(5D4) luminescence. Fluorescence sensing experiments reveal that 6-EtOH exhibits sensitive, selective, and recyclable detection of Fe3+ and Cu2+ ions through competitive absorption and dynamic processes leading to luminescence quenching. In addition, it can be used as a sensitive fluorescent probe for the rapid detection of para-substituted nitroaromatic compounds such as 4-NTP, 2,4-DNP, and TNP through fluorescence quenching by competitive absorption, photoinduced electron transfer, and electrostatic interactions. Further studies to explore the sensing behavior in response to anions and emerging pollutants such as antibiotics are in progress. In addition, monohalogenated, tetra-fluoro, -iodo, and -chloro derivatives of terephthalic acid are being employed to manipulate the strength of X···X interactions and isolate their role in promoting self-assembly of these CPs and MOFs.

Conclusions

This study reports the synthesis, characterization, and potential sensing applications of novel lanthanide MOFs based on tetrabromoterephthalic acid. Fourteen compounds, which constitute two series, were synthesized under slow evaporation conditions. Series 1, formed with the larger lanthanides, La(III)-Dy(III), is a 2D structure comprising discrete binuclear Ln-carboxylate SBUs that assemble into a sql network. Series 2 forms with Ho(III)-Lu(III) and is a unique 3D anionic framework with linear trinuclear Ln-carboxylate SBUs arranged in a pcu network topology. The framework is charge balanced by [Ln(H2O)8]3+ cations in the pores which are further encapsulated in an unprecedented 3D (H2O)12 "Star of David" dodecamer water cluster. Changing the size of the lanthanide ions changes the coordination mode of the ligand from μ3- and μ2-bridging monodentate in series 1 to only μ3-bridging monodentate in series 2 and limits the supramolecular interactions in series 2 to only Br⋅⋅⋅Br and hydrogen bonding. Furthermore, the Br⋅⋅⋅Br interactions evolve from types I, II and quasi-type I/II in series 1 to type II in series 2. The strength of type II interactions increases with decreasing size of the lanthanide(III) ion for both series 1 and 2. These results show that Br⋅⋅⋅Br interactions can be tuned by exploiting the lanthanide contraction, and these interactions can in turn be manipulated to yield Ln-MOFs whose structures and functions are predesigned and targeted. Photoluminescent studies show that TBrTA is an efficient sensitizer of both Eu3+(5D0) and Tb3+(5D4) luminescence. Fluorescence sensing experiments reveal that 6-EtOH exhibits sensitive, selective, and recyclable detection of Fe3+ and Cu2+ ions through competitive absorption and dynamic processes leading to luminescence quenching. In addition, it can be used as a sensitive fluorescent probe for the rapid detection of para-substituted nitroaromatic compounds such as 4-NTP, 2,4-DNP, and TNP through fluorescence quenching by competitive absorption, photoinduced electron transfer, and electrostatic interactions. Further studies to explore the sensing behavior in response to anions and emerging pollutants such as antibiotics are in progress. In addition, monohalogenated, tetra-fluoro, -iodo, and -chloro derivatives of terephthalic acid are being employed to manipulate the strength of X⋅⋅⋅X interactions and isolate their role in promoting self-assembly of these CPs and MOFs.

cln_elements.content: The same procedure was used in the synthesis of compounds 1–9. In a typical synthesis, solid H2TBrTA (1 mmol) was added to a warm solution of LnCl3·xH2O (8 mmol Ln3+) in 15 mL of water as it was being heated and stirred. NaOH solution (∼0.5 M) was added dropwise until pH 5.5–6.1. The reaction mixture was stirred for ∼5 min and then filtered into a warm conical flask which was covered with perforated Parafilm and placed on a sand bath at ∼90 °C. After a white thin layer formed at the bottom of the flask, the mixture was filtered once more in a conical flask which was covered with perforated Parafilm and returned to the sand bath. Three-dimensional (3D) elongated hexagonal prismatic crystals suitable for X-ray analyses were obtained after 2–5 days. Yields and IR frequencies for compounds can be seen in Table S2 of the Supporting Information.

Synthesis of Compounds 1-14 

General Syntheses of {Ln2(TBrTA)3(H2O)8⋅2H2O} n  [Ln = La (1) to Dy (9), except Pm] Compounds - Series 1 

The same procedure was used in the synthesis of compounds 1-9. In a typical synthesis, solid H2TBrTA (1 mmol) was added to a warm solution of LnCl3⋅xH2O (8 mmol Ln3+) in 15 mL of water as it was being heated and stirred. NaOH solution (~0.5 M) was added dropwise until pH 5.5-6.1. The reaction mixture was stirred for ~5 min and then filtered into a warm conical flask which was covered with perforated Parafilm and placed on a sand bath at ~90 °C. After a white thin layer formed at the bottom of the flask, the mixture was filtered once more in a conical flask which was covered with perforated Parafilm and returned to the sand bath. Three-dimensional (3D) elongated hexagonal prismatic crystals suitable for X-ray analyses were obtained after 2-5 days. Yields and IR frequencies for compounds can be seen in Table S2 of the Supporting Information.

cln_elements.content:
To study the thermal stability of the compounds, thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) and differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) analyses were performed from 25–800 °C on representative samples from each series which include compounds 4 and 14. Compound 4 records its first weight loss between 100–150 °C, which corresponds to the loss of eight coordinated and two uncoordinated water molecules (9.6% cf. theoretical 9.4%) and is accompanied by an endothermic event in the DSC signal, as expected (Figure S3). There is no further weight loss until about 400 °C where there is a significant decrease of ∼30% from 430–500 °C due to the onset of framework decomposition which continues up to 800 °C. This is accompanied by an exothermic event in the DSC signal. Compound 14 depicts a subtle change in mass from 40–100 °C which is endothermic in the DSC signal and corresponds to the loss of approximately one uncoordinated water molecule (0.5% cf. theoretical 0.5%) (Figure S3). The structure remains stable until there is a second dehydration event between 170–300 °C which corresponds to the mass loss of the remaining uncoordinated and coordinated water molecules (7.2% cf. theoretical 6.6%). The framework starts to break down shortly after as seen by the exothermic event in the DSC signal from about 350–500 °C, which continues up to 800 °C. Simulated (Sim) and as-synthesized (AS) PXRD patterns presented in Figures S4 and S5 correspond well with each other and indicate the phase purity of all samples.

Sensing Studies

Luminescent Ln-MOFs have been increasingly used in recent times as probes for the detection of small molecules, metal ions, and explosive nitroaromatic compounds (NACs) exhibiting high sensitivity and selectivity. Due to the high emission intensity of compound 6 (Eu3+), we sought to investigate its potential as a sensor for metal ions and NACs. We first investigated the luminescence intensity of 6 (2 mg) in various commonly used solvents (2 mL) to identify the most suitable solvent. As seen in a, the emission intensity of 6 is strongest in ethanol compared to other solvents such as methanol, water, acetone, acetonitrile, N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), dichloromethane (DCM), dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), cyclohexane, benzene, and toluene. Subsequently, the potential of ethanol suspensions of 6 (6-EtOH) to sense Al3+, Fe3+, Cu2+, Co2+, Hg2+, Mg2+, Ni2+, Zn2+, and Mn2+ metal ions was assessed by monitoring the Eu3+ (5D0 → 7F2) transition at 610 nm (λex = 310 nm). The extent of quenching of 5D0 → 7F2 was calculated by using : quenching efficiency = ( I 0 − I ) / I 0 × 100 % where I 0 and I are the luminescence intensities of 6-EtOH before and after interaction with metal ions, respectively. As shown in b the luminescence emission of 6-EtOH is most significantly quenched upon interaction with Fe3+ ions (87%) and Cu2+ ions (75%), while moderate quenching is observed for Co2+ and Al3+, negligible effects for Mn2+ and Ni2+ cations and a slight luminescent enhancement is seen for Hg2+, Mg2+, and Zn2+ cations. To gain a greater understanding of the luminescence response of 6 to Fe3+ and Cu2+ ions, luminescence titrations were conducted, in which incremental amounts of these analytes were added to suspensions of 6-EtOH (c–d). As expected, the luminescence intensity decreases with increasing concentration of analytes. The fluorescence quenching efficiency can be quantitatively explained by the Stern–Volmer (S–V) : ( I 0 / I ) = K SV [ Q ] + 1 where K SV is the Stern–Volmer constant/quenching effect coefficient (M–1) and [Q] is the molar concentration of the quencher. The Stern–Volmer plot for Fe3+ and Cu2+ ions is nearly linear at low concentrations (R 2 = 0.9891 for Fe3+ and 0.9893 for Cu2+) but deviate from linearity at high concentrations, which indicates that the quenching mechanism may feature both dynamic and static quenching processes or competitive absorption (i.e., inner filter effects) (e–f). The K SV values obtained at low concentrations were determined to be 6742.4 M–1 and 4612.0 M–1 for Fe3+ and Cu2+ respectively. These are comparable to K SV values in numerous studies which report CPs and MOFs as highly sensitive detectors for metal ions and demonstrate the high sensitivity of 6-EtOH toward Fe3+ and Cu2+. The limit of detection (LOD), calculated from the slope and standard error of the fitting lines (LOD = 3σ/K SV; σ = standard error of slope), is 6.79 × 10–5 mol/L (3.79 ppm) for Fe3+ and 7.52 × 10–5 mol/L (4.78 ppm) for Cu2+.

We first investigated the luminescence intensity of 6 (2 mg) in various commonly used solvents (2 mL) to identify the most suitable solvent. As seen in a, the emission intensity of 6 is strongest in ethanol compared to other solvents such as methanol, water, acetone, acetonitrile, N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), dichloromethane (DCM), dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), cyclohexane, benzene, and toluene. Subsequently, the potential of ethanol suspensions of 6 (6-EtOH) to sense Al3+, Fe3+, Cu2+, Co2+, Hg2+, Mg2+, Ni2+, Zn2+, and Mn2+ metal ions was assessed by monitoring the Eu3+ (5D0 → 7F2) transition at 610 nm (λex = 310 nm). The extent of quenching of 5D0 → 7F2 was calculated by using : 1     quenching  efficiency =  (   I   0   - I )  /   I   0   × 100 %    where I 0 and I are the luminescence intensities of 6-EtOH before and after interaction with metal ions, respectively. As shown in b the luminescence emission of 6-EtOH is most significantly quenched upon interaction with Fe3+ ions (87%) and Cu2+ ions (75%), while moderate quenching is observed for Co2+ and Al3+, negligible effects for Mn2+ and Ni2+ cations and a slight luminescent enhancement is seen for Hg2+, Mg2+, and Zn2+ cations. To gain a greater understanding of the luminescence response of 6 to Fe3+ and Cu2+ ions, luminescence titrations were conducted, in which incremental amounts of these analytes were added to suspensions of 6-EtOH (c-d). As expected, the luminescence intensity decreases with increasing concentration of analytes. The fluorescence quenching efficiency can be quantitatively explained by the Stern-Volmer (S-V) : 2      (   I   0   / I )  =   K   SV    [ Q ]  + 1    where K SV is the Stern-Volmer constant/quenching effect coefficient (M-1) and [Q] is the molar concentration of the quencher. The Stern-Volmer plot for Fe3+ and Cu2+ ions is nearly linear at low concentrations (R 2 = 0.9891 for Fe3+ and 0.9893 for Cu2+) but deviate from linearity at high concentrations, which indicates that the quenching mechanism may feature both dynamic and static quenching processes or competitive absorption (i.e., inner filter effects) (e-f). The K SV values obtained at low concentrations were determined to be 6742.4 M-1 and 4612.0 M-1 for Fe3+ and Cu2+ respectively. These are comparable to K SV values in numerous studies which report CPs and MOFs as highly sensitive detectors for metal ions and demonstrate the high sensitivity of 6-EtOH toward Fe3+ and Cu2+. The limit of detection (LOD), calculated from the slope and standard error of the fitting lines (LOD = 3σ/K SV; σ = standard error of slope), is 6.79 × 10-5 mol/L (3.79 ppm) for Fe3+ and 7.52 × 10-5 mol/L (4.78 ppm) for Cu2+.

Sensing of Nitroaromatic Compounds

The rapid and sensitive detection of explosive nitroaromatic compounds (NACs) is of importance in homeland security, environmental safety, and human health due to the detrimental effects of these compounds. In light of this, we explored the potential of 6-EtOH to sense NACs by monitoring the intensity of Eu3+ (5D0 → 7F2) transition before and after addition of nitrobenzene (NB), 1,3-dinitrobenzene (1,3-DNB), 1,3,5-trinitrobenzene (TNB), 3-nitrophenol (3-NTP), 4-nitrophenol (4-NTP), 2,4-dinitrophenol (2,4-DNP), 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP), 3,5-nitrobenzoic acid (3,5-DNTBA), 3-nitrobenzaldehyde (3-NBZAL), 3-nitroaniline (3-NTAN), 4-nitroaniline (4-NTAN), and 2-nitrotoluene (2-NTT). Studies were also carried out with phenol and aniline (AN) to comparatively assess the effect of the nitro group on the quenching efficiency of the analyte. Phenol presents a weak enhancing effect on the Eu3+ (5D0 → 7F2) emission of 6-EtOH, but all other aromatic compounds quenched the emission by varying degrees (). The order of quenching efficiency was 2,4-DNP > 4-NTP > TNP > 4-NTAN > 3-NTP > 2-NTT > 1,3-DNB > 3-NTAN > aniline > 3,5-DNTBA > TNB > 3-NBZAL > NB > phenol. This deviates slightly from the titration experiments which yielded the highest K SV for 4-NTP (11037.7 M-1) followed by 2,4-DNP (8378.8 M-1) and TNP (7320.1 M-1) (). The discrepancy may arise due to greater interaction of 4-NTP with 6-EtOH upon incremental addition during the titrations, resulting in a more accurate representation of the luminescence quenching behavior. Incremental addition of 4-NTP, 2,4-DNP, and TNP to 6-EtOH results in a progressive reduction in luminescence intensity (). The calculated LOD is 1.70 × 10-5 mol/L (2.37 ppm) for 4-NTP, 4.31 × 10-5 mol/L (7.94 ppm) for 2,4-DNP, and 7.46 × 10-5 mol/L (17.10 ppm) for TNP which are comparable to other reported MOF structures used for the detection of NACs. The Stern-Volmer plots for 4-NTP and 2,4-DNP are linear from low to high concentrations, suggesting that dynamic or static processes may contribute to the quenching of Eu3+ (5D0 → 7F2) emission. The Stern-Volmer plot for TNP is linear at low concentrations but deviates from linearity at higher concentrations with an upward curvature, which suggests that static and dynamic quenching processes may be acting simultaneously or there may be competitive absorption which leads to an inner filter effect. UV-vis absorption spectra of the analytes in ethanol show strong overlap between the excitation spectrum of 6 and the absorption spectra of 4-NTP, 2,4-DNP, TNP, and 4-NTAN, suggesting that there is competitive absorption for the excitation energy at 310 nm (Figure S9). Further comparison of phenol and aniline with their nitro congeners show that the presence of the nitro group and its location at the para- position enhances the quenching efficiency. Luminescence quenching of Ln-MOFs by NACs is known to involve photoinduced electron transfer from the conduction band of the MOF to LUMOs of the electron deficient nitroaromatic analyte. In addition, disruption of the supramolecular structure of the MOF by electrostatic forces such as π-π and hydrogen bonding interactions can also lead to quenching. IR data of compound 6 immersed in the NACs show that the structure remains the same, but a broadening of the peaks indicate that there may be electrostatic interactions of the NACs with the framework (Figure S10). Recyclability studies carried out with 4-NTP, 2,4-DNP, and TNP reveal that the initial luminescence intensity is not significantly affected even after five sensing-recovery cycles; hence, 6-EtOH is a highly regenerative probe for the detection of nitroaromatic compounds (Figure S11). Although further studies, including theoretical considerations and lifetime measurements, are needed to better understand quenching in these systems, competitive absorption, photoinduced electron transfer, and electrostatic processes likely play a significant role in the sensing of NACs by 6-EtOH.
